Earthquake relief night after night

Since the strong earthquake in Turkey and neighboring Syria, rescue teams from dozens of countries have been working day and night in the ruins of thousands of buildings destroyed by the earthquake to rescue survivors buried under the rubble.
In the freezing temperatures, they often urge quiet because they struggle to hear any sound of life from the old concrete piles.
According to Reuters today, two more women were rescued after days of being trapped in the rubble of the earthquake.
However, the death toll from the earthquake has risen to 24,150.
The death toll in Turkey is 20,665, and in Syria it is more than 3,500.

The 7.8 magnitude earthquake on Monday, which continued several times in Turkey and Syria, was the seventh deadliest natural disaster of the century, surpassing the 2011 earthquake and tsunami in Japan and approaching the 31,000 deaths caused by the 2003 earthquake in neighboring Iran.
A similar strong earthquake in northwestern Turkey in 1999 killed more than 17,000 people.
Turkish authorities said Saturday that two women were rescued from the rubble of a collapsed building in Turkey after being trapped for 122 hours after the region's deadliest earthquake in 20 years.
The other injured man, identified as Masallah Cicek, 55, was rescued from the rubble of a collapsed building in Diyarbakir, Turkey's largest city in the southeast.
In the freezing temperatures, rescuers often urge people to remain calm as they struggle to hear any sound of life from the crumbling concrete piles.
In the Samandag district of Turkey, rescuers, lying under concrete slabs, whispered "Inshallah, God bless you" and carefully reached into the rubble to rescue a 10-day-old newborn baby.
His big eyes, baby Yagiz Ulas were wrapped in a warm blanket and carried to the battlefield hospital.
Video footage shows that the paramedics also took away his mother, who was lying on the stretcher with a bruised head and pale face, but with a clear mind.
Turkish Vice President Fuat Oktay told reporters overnight that 67 people had been rescued from the rubble in the past 24 hours, with 31,000 rescue workers deployed in the affected areas.
He said that about 80,000 people were being treated in hospitals, while 105,000 were homeless due to the earthquake, and they were crammed into temporary shelters.
As many people lack food in the cold winter conditions, the public is increasingly questioning the response of the leaders of both countries to the disaster.
Syrian state media said President Bashar al-Assad and his wife, Asma, were traveling to a hospital in Aleppo, reportedly for the first time since the earthquake.
Earlier, the World Food Program said that its supplies in rebel-held northwestern Syria were about to run out due to the war situation complicating the rescue effort.
On Friday, Erdogan visited Turkey's Adana province, where he acknowledged that the government's response was not as fast as expected.
Opponents seized the issue to attack Erdogan, who is running for re-election in the May 14 vote, but may be delayed due to the disaster.
Anger over the delay in providing aid and launching rescue efforts could affect the election, according to Reuters.
Even before the earthquake, voting was seen as the most serious challenge to Erdogan's two decades in power.
Erdoğan called for unity and condemned what he called a "negative campaign for political gain".
Turkey's main opposition party leader Kemal Kilidaroğlu criticized the government's response.
Critics say the earthquake was large, but what was more serious than the earthquake was the lack of coordination, lack of planning and incompetence.

Finally gathered together, the title <unk> When we talk about love, what are we talking about?

I think this collection of novels, and its title, is like a kind of art of action, the author wants to express that love is not only a sad separation on the stage, the sea of dry stones in urban legends, not only the paint of your mother's house, love is not only above and should not be represented above, love is also a dull life, a dull and tasteless day and night, there is also a desperate escape from life, a reality.
When you read this book, you may think back to the couple you were fighting with, the unhealthy marriage of the person you knew, and the unpleasant feelings you had.

That's why I don't recommend reading it, because from an aesthetic point of view, the writing and the plot of the book are completely tasteless, unless your life is as scary or sweet as living in a candy castle, otherwise you have to read it with a sense of wonder and boredom.

And from a deeper perspective, the daily plot doesn't give you a glimpse or expand your mind and your vision (unlike Marx's "Love in the Time of Trouble"), and the short segment doesn't explore any questions, such as what kind of mistakes led to the failure of love?
Are the reasons for the breakdown of the main character's marriage?
So I don't recommend reading this book, it doesn't mean much if you don't read it.

The first factor in determining a person's job satisfaction is not salary, but whether they are given enough attention and recognition at work.

According to Maslow's hierarchy of needs, the most urgent thing after a person's basic survival needs are met is the satisfaction of psychological needs, the hope of being understood, the hope of being affirmed, the hope of being recognized.
Indeed, for the national people, most of the "love you in your heart" is hard to say, even if there is love, gratitude and praise are silently put in the heart and not spoken.
The author describes five languages of praise in the book: affirmative speech, careful timing, service, praise, gifts, body touch.

I think it's important not to know what the five languages of praise are, but to be able to use them from the bottom of your heart at any time, anywhere, to praise and thank the people around you, whether it's family, friends or colleagues.
In fact, the closer we are to each other, the more we need to be appreciated and thanked, and that's how our lives become better.
